scene.name: scene_grotto
scene.title: grotto

hotspot.name: AustinText
hotspot.html: This drawing shows the historic Austin hall in 1930. Austin hall was built in 1924 as upperclassman housing to accommodate a growing student population. It was designed by famous Philadelphia architect Wilson Eyre. It still primarily houses students today.

hotspot.name: AlumniText
hotspot.html: Alumni hall is the oldest surviving building on campus, built in 1848, and expanded in 1873. This early photograph from between 1899 and 1903 shows the building among snow. The building was the main campus building for many years when Villanova was a much smaller institution. The age of the building, along with its alleged use as a hospital for civil war soldiers, has led to the creation of rumors that the building is haunted.

hotspot.name: RitaText
hotspot.html: St. Rita's hall was built in 1912(shown here in 1913) as a seminary to replace the Belle-Air mansion that had burned down that year. Built as a seminary, today it houses the Campus Ministry as well as student dorms. It is currently undergoing major rennovation works. Click to see an early 1900s photograph of the Belle-Air mansion.

hotspot.name: BelleText
hotspot.html: The Belle Air mansion, built in 1806 was a part of the Belle-Air estate, owned by merchant and former Revolutionary War Lieutenant John Rudolph. Rudolph was a Catholic and would even allow mass to be held at the estate. In 1841, 3 years after Rudolph's death, the estate was sold to the Augustinians, who used the land to establish a monastery and the college that became Villanova. The mansion had served many functions throughout Villanova's early history, including housing, a church, and a seminary.

scene.name: scene_IMG_2158_Panorama
scene.title: IMG_2158 Panorama

hotspot.name: VillanText
hotspot.html: For a period of Villanova's history the Wildcat mascot was a literal, feral, baby wildcat. Pictured is Count Villan II, one of 4 mascots named Count Villan. Click to see more of Count Villan's story.

hotspot.name: Villan2Text
hotspot.html: Count Villan II pictured with members of the football team, 1945.

hotspot.name: Villan3Text
hotspot.html: Count Villan II meeting the Navy football team's goat mascot at the Villanova Navy game, 1945.

hotspot.name: BarryText
hotspot.html: John Barry hall was built in 1947 to serve Villanova's Naval ROTC. It was named after Commodore John Barry, an American revolutionary regarded as the Father of the US Navy.

hotspot.name: tolfireText
hotspot.html: Tolentine Hall(Formerly called Mendel hall) and the adjoining St. Thomas of Villanova Monastery have been the victim of fires, with Tolentine suffering a fire in 1928, and the monastery burning in 1932. This newspaper clipping covers the 1932 monastery fire.

scene.name: scene_kennedy_pano3
scene.title: kennedy_pano3

hotspot.name: ConnellyText
hotspot.html: The Connelly Center was completed in 1980. This image shows the dedication ceremony on September 21, 1980, with Cardinal Krol, the Archbishop of of Philadelphia, blessing the new building.

hotspot.name: SkyText
hotspot.html: Villanova's history is a history of change. This aerial view taken in 1964 shows campus at the time. The university and its facilities have expanded significantly since then. Click on the image to Villanova's even smaller campus in 1950.

hotspot.name: KennedyText
hotspot.html: Kennedy hall was built in 1969, and was named for US President John F. Kennedy in 1969. JFK received an honorary diploma from Villanova in 1957. Today it houses the university bookstore, a mailroom, and offices.

scene.name: scene_IMG_1971_Panorama
scene.title: IMG_1971 Panorama

hotspot.name: ChurchText
hotspot.html: The St. Thomas of Villanova Church, constructed in the Gothic Revival style, has long been the centerpiece of campus since its completion in 1887, with the building's architecture becoming symbolic of the University. The Church underwent major renovations in 1943 and 1992.

hotspot.name: armyText
hotspot.html: This image from 1918 shows the Villanova College Army Unit that had served in World War I. Villanova students have served in many US conflicts, including the Civil War, during which campus served as a military hospital for the Union army.
